title: Complaints about banks’ packaged accounts soar to 1,000 a week | Money
text:
Complaints to the financial ombudsman about fee-paying packaged current accounts have soared to 1,000 a week, making them the second most complained about financial product after payment protection insurance.
The Financial Ombudsman Service has been receiving batches of complaints submitted by claims management firms, many of which have switched their attention from PPI to encouraging people to claim compensation for alleged packaged account mis-selling.
Banks have begun setting aside large sums for potential compensation relating to the accounts, which can charge customers up to £204 a year and offer benefits such as travel insurance and card protection. Barclays disclosed on 29 July that it was putting aside £250m , and the following day Royal Bank of Scotland said it was lifting its provision to £307m.
Lloyds and Bank of Scotland have the Silver and Platinum packaged accounts, which cost £9.95 and £17 a month respectively, while NatWest and RBS have Select Silver and Select Platinum, costing £10 and £16 a month.
But packaged accounts have long been criticised by many commentators – consumer organisation Which? labelled them a “useless financial product” – while customers have complained they were “unfairly pressured” into signing up to an account they did not need.
Others have said to the ombudsman they were told they could not have the mortgage or loan they wanted unless they also took out a packaged account.
There have also been complaints that when customers came to claim on the insurance that is often a big selling point of these accounts, they were told they were ineligible.
In mid-2014, complaints to the financial ombudsman about these accounts were running at around 50 a week, though within a few months the figure had risen to 300-400 a week. The ombudsman service has now revealed it is receiving around 1,000 new complaints a week.
However, the banks are likely to be cheered by the ombudsman’s disclosure that with packaged account complaints, the “uphold rate” – where it finds in the customer’s favour – is just 10%, compared with an average rate for financial products of 57%. This may suggest many people are trying their luck with a claim through a management firm. There is no indication of how many complaints the banks have paid out on without the ombudsman’s involvement.
About 80% of the complaints are being submitted by claims firms. The ombudsman service indicated it was surprised to see claims firms taking such a keen interest because most packaged account claims do not involve amounts of money as high as PPI claims.
“We have concentrated our efforts on working with these businesses so they understand our approach,” it said. “As a result, some claims managers have withdrawn a large number of generic complaints where it’s clear the case isn’t going to succeed or we agree with the compensation offered by the bank.”
While some claims firms have attempted to suggest fee-paying accounts are the next big banking scandal after PPI, the ombudsman rejected this interpretation.
“Packaged accounts are different to PPI – a product that was widely mis-sold,” it said. “Though undoubtedly some people were signed up who didn’t want, couldn’t use or didn’t need the accounts, for many people, the benefits packaged with the accounts were widely used. For example, mobile phone and travel insurance, preferential rates for overdrafts etc.”
